contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} [[File:Van Denburgh John 1872-1924.png|thumb|230px|right|John Van Denburgh.]] '''John Van Denburgh''' (August 23, 1872 - 1924) was a [[United States|U.S.]] [[herpetologist]] from [[California]]. He was born in [[San Francisco]] and enrolled at [[Stanford University]] in 1891. As of 1895, he organized the herpetology department of the [[California Academy of Sciences]]. In 1897 he got a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] from Stanford University. Additionally, he got an [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]] from [[Johns Hopkins University|Johns Hopkins]] in 1902 and subsequently practiced medicine in San Francisco, while again serving as curator of the herpetological collections of the California Academy of Sciences. After the [[San Francisco earthquake of 1906]] he was instrumental in rebuilding the lost herpetology collections through new expeditions and also acquisitions of other collections. In 1922, he published the two-volume ''The Reptiles of Western North America''. He died in 1924 while on vacation in [[Hawaii]]. {{Authority control|VIAF=218062268}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Van Denburgh, John | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American zoologist | DATE OF BIRTH = August 23, 1872 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1924 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Van Denburgh, John}} [[Category:American zoologists]] [[Category:American herpetologists]] [[Category:People from San Francisco, California]] [[Category:1872 births]] [[Category:1924 deaths]] [[Category:Scientists from the San Francisco Bay Area]] {{US-zoologist-stub}}
